Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 54205-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2021 
 
 
 
Enhancing Trade Facilitation in Southeast Asia 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  BIMP-EAGA  –  Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines East 
ASEAN Growth Area 
  COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 
  Lao PDR  –  Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  WTO TFA  –  World Trade Organization Trade Facilitation Agreement 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
Vice-President  Ahmed M. Saeed, Operations 2 
Director General  Ramesh Subramaniam, Southeast Asia Department (SERD)  
Deputy Director  Winfried F. Wicklein, SERD 
General 
Director  Jose Antonio R. Tan; Public Management, Financial Sector and 
Trade Division (SEPF); SERD  
   
Team leader  Kanya S. Sasradipoera, Senior Trade Specialist, SEPF, SERD 
Team members  Florissa V. Barot, Project Analyst, SEPF, SERD 
Jenamae Dajay-Java, Operations Assistant, SEPF, SERD 
Loretta C. Jovellanos, Senior Economics Officer, SEPF, SERD 
  Taro Sekiguchi, Trade Specialist, SEPF, SERD 
Peer reviewer  Nguyen Ba Hung; Senior Regional Cooperation Specialist; Regional 
Cooperation  and  Integration  Thematic  Group;  Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will implement trade facilitation 
initiatives to enhance customs administrations in the selected developing member countries 
(DMC) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Southeast Asia.1 It will help (i) implement 
selected provisions of the World Trade Organization Trade Facilitation Agreement (WTO TFA), 
(ii) strengthen engagement with the private sector, and (iii) advocate best practices and benefits 
of trade facilitation. The TA is aligned with operational priorities of the ADB Strategy 2030 on 
accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality  (OP2),  strengthening  governance  and  institutional 
capacity (OP6), and fostering regional cooperation and integration (OP7)2. It is also linked to 
ADB’s Operational Plan for Priority 7 Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2019–2024, 
which  focuses  on  (i) greater  and  higher  quality  connectivity  between  economies,  and 
(ii) expanded global and regional trade and investment opportunity.3 The TA is included in the 
respective country operations business plans for Cambodia,4 Indonesia,5 and the Philippines6 for 
2021–2023. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Trade facilitation as one of the key measures in Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations integration. Trade facilitation plays a critical role in reducing trade cost by simplifying, 
modernizing, and harmonizing trade procedures. A study shows that full implementation of the 
WTO TFA could reduce trade costs by an average of 14.3%, shorten the average time needed to 
import goods by 47.0% and to export goods by 91.0%, and boost global trade by up to $1 trillion 
per year, with the biggest gains in the poorest countries.7 The Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN) Economic Community Blueprint 2025 and its Strategic Action Plans on Trade 
Facilitation place priority on facilitating seamless movement of goods within ASEAN, which is also 
one of the main chapters of the ASEAN free trade agreements with its main trading partners, 
including  the  Regional  Comprehensive  Economic  Partnership  (RCEP).8 The  ASEAN  trade 
facilitation measures go beyond the provisions in the WTO TFA. Recent achievements in ASEAN 
include (i) the live operation of the ASEAN Single Window between all 10 ASEAN member states 
for the Certificate of Origin (Form D) under the ASEAN Trade in Goods Agreement, and (ii) roll-out 
of ASEAN-wide self-certification. The ASEAN customs administrations are also committed to 
developing a cooperation mechanism for mutual recognition of authorized economic operators.9 
 
1  The selected DMCs are Cambodia and Lao People’s Democratic Republic. Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, 
and the Philippines are participating as members of  the Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines 
East ASEAN Growth Area (BIMP-EAGA) subregional group. All selected DMCs are members of the Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).  
2  ADB. 2018. Manila. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the 
Pacific. Manila. 
3  ADB.  2019.  Strategy  2030 Operational  Plan  for  Priority  7  Fostering  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration, 
2019–2024. Manila. https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/institutional-document/495981/strategy-2030-op7-regio 
 
nal-cooperation-integration.pdf 
4  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Cambodia, 2021–2023. Manila. 
5  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Indonesia, 2021–2023. Manila. 
6  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Philippines, 2021–2023. Manila. 
7  World Trade Organization. World Trade Report 2015.  
8  The RCEP is a mega free trade agreement that ASEAN entered into in November 2020 with the People’s Republic 
of China, Japan, the Republic of Korea, India, and Australia–New Zealand. The agreement covers a market of 
2.2 billion people, or almost 30% of the world's population, with a combined gross domestic product of $26.2 trillion, 
about 30% of global GDP, and accounts for nearly 28% of global trade (based on 2019 figures). ASEAN has been 
implementing an “ASEAN + 1” free trade agreement with each of the RCEP participating countries in the partnership.  
9  Certificate of Origin (Form D) is a prerequisite for importers within the ASEAN member states to claim preferential 
duty treatment under the ASEAN Trade in Goods Agreement.

2   
3.  With the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, the ASEAN member states put in 
place control measures in an effort to curtail the spread of COVID-19, such as movement 
restrictions and border closures, leading to limited movement of goods across borders and 
disrupted production of goods and services. Responding to this, ASEAN leaders adopted the 
Hanoi Plan of Action which underlined the importance of ensuring the smooth flow of essential 
goods at borders, while refraining from imposing unnecessary nontariff measures that are against 
WTO rules and disciplines.10  
 
4.  Implementation gaps within and among Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
member  states.  While  progress  has  been  made  in  ASEAN  trade  facilitation,  effective 
implementation of the initiatives can only be achieved if all member states are at the same level 
of  operational capacity.  Within  ASEAN, there are  differing  levels  of capacity to  implement 
international and ASEAN standards and commitments. Subregional groupings within Southeast 
Asia, such as BIMP-EAGA, play an important role as they spur development in remote and less-
developed areas within the member states.11  Implementation of the WTO TFA has been 
challenging, especially for some ASEAN member states such as Cambodia and Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic (Lao PDR). A large number of category C provisions still exist, which require 
specific implementation periods and capacity building support. For example, Cambodia has 6 
category C provisions and the Lao PDR has 17 such provisions.12 Under the customs category of 
the World Bank’s Logistics Performance Index, Cambodia and the Lao PDR were ranked 109 and 
74, respectively, among 160 economies.13  
 
5.  Strengthening  private  sector  engagement.  While  customs  administrations  are 
responsible for the clearance of goods crossing borders, the private sector, including small and 
medium-sized enterprises, plays an increasingly important role in trade facilitation services. The 
common message from private sector agents engaged in cross-border trade (such as importers, 
exporters,  freight  forwarders,  customs  brokers,  port  operators,  and  warehouse  operators, 
collectively referred to as the trade-related private sector) is that customs formalities remain the 
major impediment to improved logistics and efficient supply chains. Another common complaint 
is the lack of business-friendly information about customs procedures, regulations, and standards. 
Engaging the private sector through dialogue to design and introduce any new and/or enhanced 
trade facilitation measures is therefore important to ensure effective implementation of such 
measures. 
 
6.  Continued ADB support is critical. ADB has been supporting trade facilitation, mainly 
through TA in subregional cooperation programs within the Southeast Asian region, which has 
 
10 ASEAN. 2020. Hanoi Plan of Action on Strengthening ASEAN Economic Cooperation and Supply Chain Connectivity 
in Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic.  
11 BIMP-EAGA covers the entire sultanate of Brunei Darussalam; the Indonesian provinces of Kalimantan, Sulawesi, 
Maluku, and West Papua; the Malaysian states of Sabah and Sarawak and the federal territory of Labuan; and the 
Philippines island of Mindanao and province of Palawan. One of the strategic priorities for the trade and investment 
facilitation sector under the BIMP‑EAGA Vision 2025 is facilitating cross-border trade to address the challenges of 
cumbersome rules, regulations, and procedures in the subregion, as well as streamlining such rules, regulations, 
and procedures. https://bimp-eaga.asia/sites/default/files/publications/bimp-eaga-vision-2025.pdf. 
12 WTO TFA category C provisions are provisions for which a developing country designates a specific date for 
implementation, following a transition period during which the country is required to acquire implementation capacity. 
World Trade Organization. TFA Database (accessed on 23 September 2021). 
13 World Bank. 2018. Connecting to Compete 2018. Washington, DC. The World Bank’s Logistics Performance Index 
provides ranking based on an evaluation and calculation of efficiency of customs clearance processes. Other 
developing ASEAN countries are ranked as follows: Brunei Darussalam 73, Indonesia 62, Malaysia 43, Philippines 
85, Thailand 36, and Viet Nam 41.

3 
helped strengthen regional connectivity in ASEAN.14 Under the most recent TA, time release 
studies were conducted in Cambodia and the Philippines.15 The reports from the studies included 
a set of policy recommendations which were subsequently included in the national action plans 
of the countries as required. Support has also been provided for specific areas, such as for 
authorized economic operators in the Philippines and an ongoing feasibility study on cargo 
tracking in Cambodia. A training workshop on authorized economic operators was also conducted 
for BIMP-EAGA’s customs officials. While progress has been made, much still needs to be done. 
Continued ADB support will be instrumental to advancing the momentum created from recently 
completed TA projects toward enhanced trade facilitation in Southeast Asia. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA will build on the support provided under the recently completed TA projects with 
Cambodia  and  the  Lao  PDR  as  participating countries  and  BIMP-EAGA  as  a  subregional 
grouping.16 The TA is aligned with the following impact: to achieve competitive, efficient, and 
seamless movement of goods within the Southeast Asia region.17 The outcome of the TA will be 
improved trade facilitation measures in the participating ASEAN member states.  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  The  TA  will  have  the  following  three  outputs:  (i)  selected  WTO TFA  provisions 
implemented, (ii) private sector engagement strengthened, and (iii) best practices and benefits of 
trade facilitation advocated and disseminated.18  
 
9.  Output  1:  Selected  World  Trade  Organization  Trade  Facilitation  Agreement 
provisions implemented. The TA will assist customs administrations in Cambodia and Lao PDR 
select and implement up to two prioritized provisions of the WTO TFA under the countries’ 
respective category C (footnote 12). A gap assessment between the status and the WTO TFA 
requirements for the selected provisions will be completed. Based on this assessment, a work 
plan  will  be  developed  which  will  include  the  level  of  compliance,  targeted  timelines,  and 
necessary actions to be taken to implement the WTO TFA requirements. The actions in the work 
plan will include: (i) technical advisory support, such as legal support and practical advice, to 
effectively implement the provisions and review laws and regulations to ensure compliance with 
the selected WTO TFA provisions; and (ii) implementation support including the development of 
standard operating procedures, complemented by capacity building for customs officials and other 
 
14  ADB.  2016.  Completion  Report:  Trade  Facilitation  Support  for  ASEAN  Economic  Community  Blueprint 
Implementation  (GMS/Indonesia-  Malaysia-Thailand  Growth  Triangle).  Manila. 
https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-document/185366/45100-001-tcr.pdf, ADB 2018. Completion Report: 
Strengthening Trade Facilitation in the Greater Mekong Subregion through Partnerships with the Private Sector. 
Manila.  https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-documents/46191/46191-001-tcr-en.pdf.  ADB.2018. 
Completion Report: Technical Assistance for Strengthening Institutional Knowledge and Capacity of Customs 
Administrations  for  Trade  Facilitation  within  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations.  Manila. 
https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-documents/46192/46192-001-tcr-en.pdf,  ADB.2020.  Completion 
Report: Support for Implementing the Action Plan for Transport and Trade Facilitation in the Greater Mekong 
Subregion. Manila. https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-documents/44174/44174-012-tcr-en.pdf. 
15 ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance for Advancing Time Release Studies in Southeast Asia. Manila. The reports on 
Time Release Studies supported by the TA were submitted to the ASEAN Secretariat as inputs to their review on 
ASEAN Seamless Trade Facilitation Indicators (ASTFI). The TA will continue the practice of sharing its outputs with 
ASEAN, for consideration of their contribution to ASTFI. 
16 The Lao PDR indicated its interest to be a participating country of the TA during the fact-finding mission in May 2021. 
17 ASEAN Secretariat. 2015. ASEAN Economic Blueprint 2025. Jakarta.  
18 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4   
government agencies, to effectively implement the selected WTO TFA provisions. The TA will 
support the implementation of selected initiatives under the BIMP-EAGA customs cooperation 
work plan to be implemented in accordance with the WTO TFA provisions. The TA will also 
provide technical expertise and support in line with the related provisions of the World Customs 
Organization Revised Kyoto Convention and SAFE Framework.19 
 
10.  Output 2: Private sector engagement strengthened. Engagement with trade related 
private sector entities is quite critical, as they are directly affected by trade facilitation measures 
and could provide inputs on issues requiring further facilitation. It is also important to ensure they 
understand the trade facilitation measures to maximize the benefits of such measures. The TA 
will help customs administrations in Cambodia and Lao PDR engage effectively with such entities 
through public consultations and dissemination of business-friendly information on issues such 
as new customs procedures and the provision of support services. Supporting information outside 
the jurisdiction of customs administrations, such as availability of financing measures to support 
export activities, will also be included where necessary. Such information will be disseminated 
through various means, including the websites of customs administrations, booklets in local 
languages, establishment of help desks on customs matters, and outreach sessions for dialogue.  
 
11.  Output  3:  Best  practices  and  benefits  of  trade  facilitation  advocated  and 
disseminated. The TA will support knowledge-sharing events for the participating countries  with 
other  ASEAN  Member  States,  to  share  experiences  and  lessons  with  public  and  private 
 
stakeholders,  including  industry,  business,  and  trade  associations.20 Various  topics  will  be 
discussed at the events, including best practices in the implementation of various WTO TFA 
provisions, ASEAN trade facilitation initiatives, emerging issues such as the role of customs 
agencies in climate change, and opportunities for collaboration between subregional groupings 
that are promoting convergence on trade facilitation initiatives among the ASEAN member states. 
The knowledge-sharing events may be convened through remote video technology meetings, in 
lieu of face-to-face meetings, as necessary. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. The Southeast Asia Department’s Public Management, 
Financial Sector and Trade Division will implement the TA in consultation with the department's 
resident missions and other sector divisions. Country coverage includes selected DMCs in 
Southeast Asia (footnote1). ADB will engage the consultants and resource persons as necessary 
following ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff 
instructions. Indicative implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. Beyond the 
TA implementation period, progress of TA outcome will continue to be monitored under BIMP-
EAGA  progress  reports,  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Cross  Border  Transport  Facilitation’s 
 
19 In June 2005, the World Customs Organization Council adopted the SAFE Framework of Standards to Secure and 
Facilitate Global Trade that would secure revenue collections, promote trade facilitation worldwide, and act as a 
deterrent to international terrorism. 
20 Given that the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) only provides support for international travel for officials in 
special circumstances, the knowledge-sharing sessions will be organized back-to-back within the participating 
subregional groupings and regional forums. In cases where there are participation costs of officials, participants from 
high-income countries (e.g., Brunei Darussalam) will be expected to bear the cost of their participation in the session.

5 
Customs Sub-committee report, as well as during regular dialogue between ADB and the ASEAN 
Secretariat.21

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
14.  Consulting services. The TA will require 30 person-months of international consultant 
services and 20 person-months of national consultant services. ADB will engage, supervise, and 
evaluate the consultants, and carry out procurement following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as 
amended from time to time). Both international and national individual consultants will be engaged 
using  the  individual  consultant  selection  method  through  the  ADB-managed  consultant 
management system.22  
 
15.  Cofinancier requirements. During the implementation of the TA, semiannual progress 
reports, including an overview of the expenditures, will be provided to the Government of Japan 
(GOJ). Any changes to the objectives or the scope of the TA during the implementation will be 
discussed with the GOJ. The TA completion report will be shared with the GOJ.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Enhancing Trade Facilitation in Southeast Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
21 ADB is the Development Advisor of BIMP-EAGA and the Secretariat of GMS CBTA Customs Sub-committee. ADB 
also conducts regular consultations with the ASEAN Secretariat on Trade and Transport Facilitation issues.  
22 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1  Selected WTO TFA provisions implemented  
1.1 Identify the priority provisions of the WTO TFA for each participating country (Q4 2021)  
1.2 Conduct gap analyses of the selected provisions of the WTO TFA (Q1 2022)  
1.3 Develop a work plan to implement the selected provisions of the WTO TFA (Q2 2022)  
1.4 Implement the work plan (Q2 2022–Q2 2024) 
2  Private sector engagement strengthened 
2.1 Organize consultations and outreach sessions with trade-related private sector either face-to-face or 
through online trainings and/or webinars (Q4 2021–Q2 2024) 
2.2 Develop gender-responsive and inclusive information materials for consultation with and outreach to 
the trade-related private sector (Q4 2021–Q1 2024) 
3  Best practices and benefits of trade facilitation advocated and disseminated 
3.1 Organize face-to-face or online  regional knowledge-sharing event (Q2 2022–Q2 2024) 
 
3.2 Develop gender-responsive and inclusive knowledge products on trade facilitation issues 
(Q2 2022–Q2 2024)
 
 
TA Management Activities 
Mobilize consultants (Q4 2021–Q1 2022) 
Conduct monitoring and evaluation (Q4 2022, Q3 2023)
